content.description: Follow a seam up to a face with decent holds. This leads to the first crux which is a clip on a small crimp and then pulling over a diagonal edge.  The route heads straight up to some overhanging huecos, pumping, but good holds.  The route finishes on a lower angle slab which is likely the real crux.  You can attack it from a few different directions.
content.protection: 8 bolts with a double bolted anchor on top.  Be mindful of rope drag.
content.location: From the trail to the top of Main Street follow the gulley to the right down the cliff.  The route starts past a fallen tree.

content.description: A highly diverse route. One of my favorites from my visit to Hills Creek. Climb the crack to a corner and veer left up and over a bulge to finish the climb as the steep lessens.  All sorts of different techniques and rock formations on this one.
content.protection: There are top rope anchors accessible from the trail.  If you want to lead, it uses roughly 8 bolts and a #2 Camalot in place of the second bolt, which is likely a must have to avoid decking.
content.location: The trail leads to the top of Main Street, on the left side you will find two sets of anchors.  East End Boys is the right set.  Rappelling down will save you a hairy approach down the cliff.  Use the single bolt belay at the top of the low angle slab.

content.description: A solid 5.11a - more technical than physical. first challenge is mantling the overhang. above are thin holds, steep balancing moves required. a bit dirty. there’s a belay bolt to clip at the base.
content.location: As the trail comes to the Spires, you’ll see the large Main Street spire directly below (south) and to your right (west). Go to the right, scrambling out past the manzanita tree. Make 2 5.7 moves to bring you to top of Main Street. The second set of anchors on your left will bring you down Draggin the Gut. Alternatively, you can take the left hand trail down but rappelling is recommended.

climbs.name: Alley Acess
climbs.fa: Peter & Chris Fralick and Randy Rimby - 2000

content.description: The closest rock to the parking area.
